title: Coding and Classifying Knowledge Exchange on Social Media: a Comparative Analysis of the #Twitterstorians and AskHistorians Communities
authors: Anatoliy Gruzd, Priya Kumar, Deena Abul-Fottouh, Caroline Haythornthwaite
hypotheses: Platform architecture significantly influences knowledge exchange patterns and community discourse structures
notes: Provides comprehensive framework for coding knowledge exchange patterns across different social media platforms. Compares Twitter vs Reddit knowledge sharing mechanisms.
strengths: Methodologically rigorous coding scheme; comparative platform analysis; focus on scholarly discourse patterns
weaknesses: Limited to academic knowledge sharing; focus on established scholarly communities rather than general interest communities
citation: Gruzd, A., Kumar, P., Abul-Fottouh, D., & Haythornthwaite, C. (2020). Coding and classifying knowledge exchange on social media: a comparative analysis of the# Twitterstorians and AskHistorians communities. Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW), 29(6), 629-656.

title: Relationships Between User Knowledge Sharing in Virtual Community with Community Loyalty and Satisfaction
authors: Jiemei Zhang, Yuejie Ma, Bei Lyu
hypotheses: Knowledge sharing behaviors in virtual communities correlate with community loyalty and user satisfaction through social validation mechanisms
notes: Empirical study examining relationships between knowledge sharing, community engagement, and user satisfaction outcomes.
strengths: Large-scale empirical validation; clear theoretical framework linking behavior to outcomes
weaknesses: Limited focus on conversation patterns vs static knowledge sharing; primarily quantitative approach
citation: Zhang, J., Ma, Y., & Lyu, B. (2021). Relationships Between User Knowledge Sharing in Virtual Community with Community Loyalty and Satisfaction. Psychology Research and Behavior Management, 14, 1509-1523.

title: Cross-national differences in travelers' continuance of knowledge sharing in online travel communities
authors: Gomaa Agag, Riyad Eid, Wael Shehawy
hypotheses: Cultural and economic development factors significantly influence knowledge sharing patterns and continuance intentions in travel communities
notes: Cross-cultural study of 6,803 travelers across four countries examining factors motivating knowledge sharing continuance.
strengths: Large sample size; cross-cultural validation; focus specifically on travel communities
weaknesses: Survey-based methodology lacks conversational pattern analysis; limited temporal dimension
citation: Agag, G., Eid, R., & Shehawy, W. (2021). Cross-national differences in travelers' continuance of knowledge sharing in online travel communities. Journal of Business Research, 128, 454-463.

title: Toward a classification of discourse patterns in asynchronous online discussions
authors: Ella L. F. Fu, Jan van Aalst, Carol K. K. Chan
journal: International Journal of Computer-Supported Collaborative Learning
hypotheses: Distinct discourse patterns can be classified to distinguish knowledge sharing, knowledge construction, and knowledge building modes
notes: Develops nine-pattern classification system for online discourse using qualitative coding and narrative analysis.
strengths: Comprehensive pattern classification; qualitative-quantitative integration; educational context validation
weaknesses: Limited to educational forums; small sample size; lacks temporal analysis
citation: Fu, E. L. F., van Aalst, J., & Chan, C. K. K. (2016). Toward a classification of discourse patterns in asynchronous online discussions. International Journal of Computer-Supported Collaborative Learning, 11(4), 441-478.

title: Computer-Mediated Discourse Analysis: An Approach to Researching Online Behavior
authors: Susan C. Herring
hypotheses: Micro-level discourse analysis can reveal macro-level social phenomena in computer-mediated communication
notes: Foundational framework for Computer-Mediated Discourse Analysis (CMDA) methodology for studying online behavior through discourse patterns.
strengths: Foundational theoretical framework; empirically grounded; avoids premature generalizations about online communities
weaknesses: General framework rather than domain-specific application; limited computational automation
citation: Herring, S. C. (2004). Computer-mediated discourse analysis: An approach to researching online behavior. Designing for virtual communities in the service of learning, 338-376.

title: Temporal analytics with discourse analysis: tracing ideas and impact on communal discourse
authors: Alwyn Vwen Yen Lee, Seng Chee Tan
hypotheses: Temporal analytics combined with discourse analysis can trace idea evolution and impact on communal discourse
notes: Pioneers methodology combining temporal analytics with step-wise discourse analysis to trace ideas through online discussions.
strengths: Novel temporal-discourse integration; idea tracing methodology; community impact measurement
weaknesses: Small sample size (281 posts); educational context only; limited scalability
citation: Lee, A. V. Y., & Tan, S. C. (2017). Temporal analytics with discourse analysis: tracing ideas and impact on communal discourse. Proceedings of the Seventh International Learning Analytics & Knowledge Conference, 383-387.

title: Patterns of Temporal Variation in Online Media
authors: Jaewon Yang, Jure Leskovec
hypotheses: Online content exhibits distinct temporal patterns that can be systematically identified and clustered
notes: Large-scale analysis of 580M tweets and 170M blog posts identifying six main temporal shapes of online attention.
strengths: Massive dataset; K-Spectral Centroid clustering algorithm; temporal pattern identification
weaknesses: Focus on content popularity rather than conversational patterns; limited to attention metrics
citation: Yang, J., & Leskovec, J. (2011). Patterns of temporal variation in online media. Proceedings of the fourth ACM international conference on Web search and data mining, 177-186.

title: How Large Language Models Can Reshape Collective Intelligence
authors: Jason W. Burton, Ezequiel Lopez-Lopez, Shahar Hechtlinger, et al.
hypotheses: Large language models can enhance rather than replace human collective intelligence through complementary capabilities
notes: Interdisciplinary perspective on AI-enhanced collective intelligence, examining opportunities and challenges for human-AI collaboration.
strengths: Comprehensive interdisciplinary approach; practical implications; future-oriented framework
weaknesses: Limited empirical validation; focus on AI integration rather than pure human collective intelligence
citation: Burton, J. W., et al. (2024). How large language models can reshape collective intelligence. Nature Human Behaviour, 8(9), 1671-1680.

title: Toward collective intelligence of online communities: A primitive conceptual model
authors: Shuangling Luo, Haoxiang Xia, Taketoshi Yoshida, Zhongtuo Wang
journal: Journal of Systems Science and Systems Engineering
hypotheses: Community intelligence emerges from interactions in knowledge supernetworks comprising media, human, and knowledge networks
notes: Conceptual model distinguishing 'knowing' (tacit) from 'knoware' (explicit, actionable) knowledge in community intelligence systems.
strengths: Integrated theoretical framework; knowledge supernetwork model; tacit-explicit knowledge distinction
weaknesses: Conceptual only without empirical validation; limited operational definitions
citation: Luo, S., Xia, H., Yoshida, T., & Wang, Z. (2009). Toward collective intelligence of online communities: A primitive conceptual model. Journal of Systems Science and Systems Engineering, 18(2), 203-221.

title: Structural Holes and Peer Knowledge Production in Professional Q&A Communities: A Middle-Range Theory of User Engagement
authors: Langtao Chen, Aaron Baird, Detmar Straub
journal: Journal of the Association for Information Systems
hypotheses: Network positions and structural holes significantly influence knowledge production and user engagement in professional Q&A communities
notes: Develops middle-range theory explaining how social network positions affect knowledge contribution patterns in professional communities.
strengths: Strong theoretical foundation; professional community focus; network position analysis
weaknesses: Limited to professional Q&A format; less applicable to casual travel forums
citation: Chen, L., Baird, A., & Straub, D. (2025). Structural holes and peer knowledge production in professional Q&A communities: A middle-range theory of user engagement. Journal of the Association for Information Systems, 26(2), Article 7.

title: Knowledge Sharing in Tension: Interacting and Documenting on Stack Overflow
authors: Thomas Hillman, Alena Seredko, Markus Nivala, Tanya Osborne
conference: CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
hypotheses: Tension exists between documenting knowledge for searchability and supporting real-time interactive problem-solving
notes: Examines how platform design affects balance between creating knowledge repositories and supporting conversational help-seeking.
strengths: Platform design implications; tension identification; practical insights for community platforms
weaknesses: Limited to technical Q&A communities; single platform focus
citation: Hillman, T., Seredko, A., Nivala, M., & Osborne, T. (2021). Knowledge sharing in tension: Interacting and documenting on Stack Overflow. Proceedings of the 2021 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems, 1-14.

title: Understanding online travel communities: a literature review and future research directions in hospitality and tourism
authors: Yuan Zhou, Woo Gon Kim, Bendegul Okumus, Cihan Cobanoglu
hypotheses: Online travel community research can be systematically categorized to identify gaps and future research directions
notes: Comprehensive literature review of 71 OTC articles (2002-2020) identifying four topical clusters and research gaps.
strengths: Comprehensive systematic review; identifies research gaps; travel-specific focus
weaknesses: Review study rather than empirical research; limited methodological innovation
citation: Zhou, Y., Kim, W. G., Okumus, B., & Cobanoglu, C. (2021). Understanding online travel communities: a literature review and future research directions in hospitality and tourism. Journal of Travel & Tourism Marketing, 38(2), 194-212.

title: Identifying Patterns among Tourism-Oriented Online Communities on Facebook
authors: Eva Zabudská, Kristína Pompurová
hypotheses: Tourism-oriented online communities exhibit distinct patterns of structural and managerial dynamics that correlate with effectiveness
notes: Develops typology of tourism communities on Facebook analyzing structural and managerial dynamics affecting engagement.
strengths: Tourism-specific focus; structural-managerial integration; community effectiveness metrics
weaknesses: Single platform (Facebook); limited to community management rather than conversational patterns
citation: Zabudská, E., & Pompurová, K. (2024). Identifying Patterns among Tourism-Oriented Online Communities on Facebook. Tourism and Hospitality, 5(3), 48.

title: Determinants of the intention to participate in firm-hosted online travel communities
authors: Luis V. Casaló, Carlos Flavián, Miguel Guinalíu
hypotheses: Participation intentions in firm-hosted travel communities are driven by Theory of Planned Behavior, Technology Acceptance, and Social Identity factors
notes: Integrates multiple theoretical frameworks to explain participation intentions in firm-hosted online travel communities.
strengths: Multi-theoretical integration; firm-hosted community focus; behavioral intention modeling
weaknesses: Limited to firm-hosted rather than organic communities; survey methodology only
citation: Casaló, L. V., Flavián, C., & Guinalíu, M. (2010). Determinants of the intention to participate in firm-hosted online travel communities. Tourism Management, 31(6), 898-911.

title: Editorial: Network analysis of social media texts
authors: Ke Jiang, Weiai Xu, James Danowski
journal: Frontiers in Research Metrics and Analytics
hypotheses: Network analysis methods can effectively illuminate structures and dynamics of social media discourse
notes: Editorial introducing network analysis approaches for social media text analysis, emphasizing semantic and coherency network analysis.
strengths: Methodological focus; semantic network emphasis; social media applicability
weaknesses: Editorial format limits empirical content; general rather than domain-specific
citation: Jiang, K., Xu, W. W., & Danowski, J. (2025). Editorial: Network analysis of social media texts. Frontiers in Research Metrics and Analytics, 10, 1558798.

title: Graph-Based Conversation Analysis in Social Media
authors: Marco Brambilla, Alireza Javadian Sabet, Kalyani Kharmale, Amin Endah Sulistiawati
hypotheses: Graph-based models can effectively capture conversation flows and structural properties in social media discussions
notes: Develops graph-based methods for modeling conversation flows, capturing structural properties and temporal dynamics.
strengths: Graph-based methodology; conversation flow modeling; structural property analysis
weaknesses: Technical methodology focus; limited domain application; lacks empirical validation on travel forums
citation: Brambilla, M., Javadian Sabet, A., Kharmale, K., & Sulistiawati, A. E. (2022). Graph-Based Conversation Analysis in Social Media. Big Data and Cognitive Computing, 6(4), 113.

title: Identifying Patterns of Collaborative Knowledge Exploration in Online Asynchronous Discussions
authors: Silvia Wen-Yu Lee, Chin-Chung Tsai
hypotheses: Collaborative knowledge exploration exhibits identifiable patterns that can be analyzed through mixed-method approaches
notes: Six-week study of 11 graduate students integrating quantitative pattern identification with qualitative interpretation.
strengths: Mixed-method integration; longitudinal design; collaborative knowledge exploration focus
weaknesses: Small sample size; educational context only; limited generalizability to travel forums
citation: Lee, S. W. Y., & Tsai, C. C. (2011). Identifying patterns of collaborative knowledge exploration in online asynchronous discussions. Instructional Science, 39(3), 321-347.

title: Capturing temporal and sequential patterns of self-, co-, and socially shared regulation in the context of collaborative learning
authors: Jonna Malmberg, Sanna Järvelä, Hanna Järvenoja
hypotheses: Sequential patterns of self-regulated, co-regulated, and socially shared regulation can be captured and analyzed in collaborative contexts
notes: Develops methodology for capturing temporal and sequential patterns of regulation in collaborative learning environments.
strengths: Temporal-sequential pattern analysis; collaborative context; regulation pattern identification
weaknesses: Educational context only; limited to regulation patterns rather than knowledge transfer
citation: Malmberg, J., Järvelä, S., & Järvenoja, H. (2017). Capturing temporal and sequential patterns of self-, co-, and socially shared regulation in the context of collaborative learning. Contemporary Educational Psychology, 49, 160-174.

title: Conversation Analytic Perspectives to Digital Interaction: Practices, Resources, and Affordances
authors: Aino Koivisto, Heidi Vepsäläinen, Mikko T. Virtanen
hypotheses: Traditional conversation analysis methods can be adapted to understand digital interaction practices and affordances
notes: Comprehensive coverage of conversation analytic approaches to digital interaction, examining practices, resources, and technological affordances.
strengths: Comprehensive methodological coverage; digital interaction focus; conversation analysis adaptation
weaknesses: General methodology rather than specific application; limited empirical examples
citation: Koivisto, A., Vepsäläinen, H., & Virtanen, M. T. (Eds.). (2023). Conversation Analytic Perspectives to Digital Interaction: Practices, Resources, and Affordances. Finnish Literature Society.

title: Persistent interaction patterns across social media platforms and over time
authors: Michele Avalle, Niccolò Di Marco, Gabriele Etta, et al.
hypotheses: Conversation patterns and user behaviors remain consistent across platforms and time periods despite technological differences
notes: Large-scale analysis across eight platforms over 34 years showing consistent conversation patterns regardless of platform, topic, or time.
strengths: Massive temporal and cross-platform scope; consistent pattern identification; toxicity analysis
weaknesses: Focus on toxicity rather than positive knowledge sharing patterns; limited to conversation length and participation
citation: Avalle, M., Di Marco, N., Etta, G., et al. (2024). Persistent interaction patterns across social media platforms and over time. Nature, 630(8016), 363-370.

title: Computational Social Science and Sociology
authors: Achim Edelmann, Tom Wolff, Danielle Montagne, Christopher A. Bail
hypotheses: Computational methods can enhance traditional sociological analysis while maintaining theoretical rigor
notes: Comprehensive review of computational social science integration with sociology, examining opportunities and challenges.
strengths: Comprehensive methodological review; theoretical-computational integration; sociological grounding
weaknesses: Review study rather than empirical application; general rather than domain-specific
citation: Edelmann, A., Wolff, T., Montagne, D., & Bail, C. A. (2020). Computational social science and sociology. Annual Review of Sociology, 46, 61-81.

title: Does Who Helps You Impact Your Behavior? Examining the Effects of Social Interactions on Knowledge Sharing in Online Communities
authors: Eunkwang Seo, Frank Nagle, Sonali Shah
journal: Harvard Business School Strategy Unit Working Paper
hypotheses: Social interaction patterns and helper characteristics significantly influence knowledge sharing behaviors in online communities
notes: Examines how social interactions affect knowledge sharing behavior, particularly focusing on new member engagement and community growth.
strengths: Social interaction focus; community growth implications; new member engagement analysis
weaknesses: Working paper status; limited to specific community types; lacks travel forum application
citation: Seo, E., Nagle, F., & Shah, S. (2020). Does who helps you impact your behavior? Examining the effects of social interactions on knowledge sharing in online communities. Harvard Business School Strategy Unit Working Paper, (21-026).

title: Why We Share: A Systematic Review of Knowledge-Sharing Intentions on Social Media Platforms
authors: Jia Hu, Shuhaida Md Noor
hypotheses: Knowledge-sharing intentions on social media are influenced by psychological, technological, environmental, and social factors centered on trust and attitude
notes: Systematic review identifying 47 determinants of knowledge-sharing intentions across four key themes, with Zhihu as the most studied platform.
strengths: Systematic methodology; comprehensive factor identification; recent publication
weaknesses: Review study rather than empirical research; limited to intentions rather than actual behavior patterns
citation: Hu, J., & Noor, S. M. (2024). Why We Share: A Systematic Review of Knowledge-Sharing Intentions on Social Media Platforms. Behavioral Sciences, 14(8), 636.
